title: Investors pay £600m in avoidance bills
text:
Tax avoidance bills deliver £600m for Revenue Adam Palin ©EPA 
Controversial demands for tax reliefs associated with contested investments generated almost three times more than forecast for the Exchequer last year, illustrating the pace of the government’s counter-avoidance drive. 
Participants in offending schemes wrote cheques to HM Revenue &Customs totalling £596m in 2014-15, having been issued with so-called accelerated payment notices. More Budget grants new powers to Revenue 
According to figures published by the tax authority, 10,000 of these demands — which cannot be appealed — were issued last year, relating to unpaid tax worth £1.7bn. 
“HMRC appear extremely well placed to meet their revenue targets, based on these figures,” said Richard Morley, a partner at accountants BDO. He added, however, that the figures indicated roughly £1bn of tax demanded had yet to be paid, in many cases following legal representation. 
Investors in a handful of the largest tax schemes have mounted legal challenges to the use of accelerated payment notices. Where applications for judicial review have been successful, as in the case of three film partnerships promoted by Ingenious Media, investors’ payment notices have been suspended pending their outcome. 
Paul Noble, a tax director at law firm Pinsent Masons, said the fact that recipients have 90 days to stump up the tax authority’s demands means thousands sent out before April will have been paid in the current tax year. 
The Revenue, which aims to raise almost £8bn through accelerated payment notices from 64,000 or so taxpayers and businesses, has noticeably scaled up production, said Mr Noble. “We saw these things coming out pretty slowly to begin with . . . then accelerate in the new year.” 
Depending on the size of a taxpayer’s investment in a given scheme, and any leverage involved, the amount that HMRC contests is due often runs in hundreds of thousands. The authority itself has indicated that some individuals face bills of more than £10m, payable before tax tribunals have ruled on their schemes.
